p.s: Description of Streptomyces turgidiscabies sp. nov.
Streptomyces turgidiscabies (tur.gi.di.sca'bi.es. L. adj. turgidus swollen; L. fem. n. scabies scabbiness; N.L. fem. n. turgidiscabies a swollen scabbiness)
The species is placed in the genus Streptomyces as it has morphology typical of this genus and cell walls with the LL-diaminopimelic acid isomer.
Spores are 0.3-0.6 x 1.0-1.2 μm, smooth, grey, and are borne in mature flexuous chains containing eight or more spores.
Diffusible pigments and melanin are not produced.
All International Streptomyces Project sugars (L-arabinose, D-fructose, D-glucose, D-mannitol, iso-inositol, rhamnose, sucrose, D-xylose and raffinose) are used as carbon sources.

All strains that have been studied do not degrade xanthine or grow at 37°C and are susceptible to 20 μg streptomycin ml-1, 0.5 μg crystal violet ml-1, 100 μg potassium tellurite ml-1 and 0.1 % phenol.
The G+C content of this species is 70.9-72-5 mol%. S. turgidiscabies differs from other potato scab pathogens in having grey, smooth, flexuous spore chains.
This strain was isolated from raised scab lesions on potato tubers in eastern Hokkaido, Japan, in 1991, and has been confirmed to be pathogenic.

It is positive for peptonization but not for coagulation of milk, is not susceptible to 25 μg oleandomycin ml-1 or 10 IU penicillin G ml-1, and is not positive for utilization of sodium acetate or sodium propionate as sole carbon sources.
